reviewText: Spoiler alert!  I warn you in advance:  I will reveal a critical piece of information that you only learn at the end of the movie.You can enjoy this movie completely even when knowing how it ends up; but if you want your first experience of it to be "pure," then stop reading here.If you do see this movie without reading this review, then I would suggest you watch it again because knowing the outcome changes your understanding of the movie.One important thing to know about this movie is that it is NOT about reincarnation.  It is about how certain people react to its possibility.  And it is about needfulness so extreme that it becomes pathological.  And it is about how we can all be blind to certain things.As part of the opening credits, we see the back view of a runner, Sean, doing his laps through Central Park.  He has a heart attack and drops dead.  We then see a picture of a baby in a womb.And it is now ten years later.  We will soon learn that Sean was married to Anna (Nicole Kidman).  Anna has taken his death very hard, so hard that only recently did she begin dating again -- Joseph (Danny Huston) -- and even more recently accept his proposal of marriage.There is now the first of two scenes in the movie that cheat the viewer.  We see a woman -- Clara (Anne Heche) -- about to arrive at a party.  She is bearing a gift.  She tells her husband to go upstairs to the party without her.  She wants to get a ribbon for the gift.  A little puzzled, he does as she asks.  She sits still for some time.  We see that a young boy notices her.  After a while, she leaves the apartment building, hurries into Central Park and buries the gift she has brought.  The young boy follows her on this journey.  She then goes into a shop and buys a replacement gift.The next scene shows a party.  The woman we have watched does not appear to be here.Nor is she at this party.  This is the sleight-of-hand that fools the watcher and may even confuse some viewers even after they have seen the entire movie.This is a different party, later in time.Here is what we are not told:First, the extent of Anna's needfulness for her dead husband.  This needfulness accounts, mostly, for all her dubious behavior to come.  One measure of her needfulness is how blind she was to his true nature when he was alive.  Essentially, the man Anna loved never existed.  The real Sean was having an affair with Clara, the wife in a couple with whom both Sean and Anna were close.  The measure of Sean's disdain for Anna was part of how he proved to Clara how much more he loved her:  He gave Clara all the unopened love letters Anna had been writing to him.Consider this:  Here is Anna, married to Sean, still so much in bliss that she writes him love letters.  And ignores the fact that he does not respond to them (he cannot, because he does not open them).  And yet she persists.  One can imagine how smothered Sean is by all this.  One can almost see how Sean would turn to another woman.  What makes him despicable is that he gives those unopened letters to his lover.We are told none of this, though.  It is for us to deduce backwards when we get to almost the end of the movie.What we see, but don't understand, is Clara showing up at this party prepared to show all the love letters to Anna, proving to Anna her husband's unfaithfulness; then changing her mind and burning the letters in a shallow hole.We see the young boy Sean, whose father tutors a child in the same apartment building, leaving him downstairs where the doorman/concierge sort of watches out for him.  We see him watching this strangely behaving woman.  We see him, a bored ten year old, following Clara into the park.  But we are not allowed to see him dig up the box of letters Clara buries there.  Nor do we see him later at home opening each letter and identifying with the addressee of the same name, the Sean Anna is so in love with, that Sean feels that love, feels he is really Anna's Sean.  We don't see him brooding, his personality changing.But we do see Sean showing up (and to us it seems like the same evening) at this other party, asking to see Anna and telling her not to marry Joseph, announcing that he is Sean.Now there is nothing wrong with hiding all the important links from us, the viewers.  If we are to perceive this from Anna's viewpoint, then we must be as ignorant as she is.  So why do I call this cheating?  One little reason: Clara's burying of the letters instead of just dumping them into a trashcan makes no sense and only is done because the picture cannot work without its happening.  And one bigger reason: We are deceived into thinking that the two consecutive scenes are separated by mere minutes instead of mere weeks.  This illusion is not necessary to the telling of the story; and it is so convincing that it is almost impossible to later recall the sequence and disentangle it.From now on, we follow Anna as she (and we) are beset by more and more convincing evidence that the boy Sean is indeed the reincarnation of dead husband Sean.  Sean has learned the contents of those love letters, and the facade of Anna's and Sean's marriage better than any ten year old mastering fractions in his spare time.Nor is Anna alone in her growing belief in Sean.  Others who knew both of them are at least dubiously credulous.But here is the second cheat, and it is even more bothersome than the first: No one seems to really care.I mean here is this kid, claiming to be the reincarnation of this man -- a nuclear physicist by all appearances -- and seeming like he might be telling the truth.  And no one is sitting down with him and asking the obvious questions."Sean, what was it like to be reincarnated?"  "Sean, do you remember that time we picked up a couple of hookers and got plastered?"  "My God, Sean, how can you stand being ten years old and having acne?"  "Isn't it cool, getting to start over again and avoid all those mistakes you made?"Yes, there is a short scene in which an acquaintance asks some "telling" questions ... until the interview stops.What is wrong with these people?!  Why isn't a single one of them excited?Well, Anna is excited, but only at the prospect of having Sean back.  How he got back seems totally irrelevant.  (Of course, in Anna's case this is quite consistent with the kind of clueless existence she had already been living with Sean.)  But still, doesn't anyone (anyone!) want to know what it's like for an adult to be trapped in the body of a ten year old?  Not in this movie, it seems.Okay, so angst all over the place.  Anna is convinced.  Most people aren't.  The boy friend wants to beat the kid up and actually tries to do just this.  This is tedious enough when we don't know what is happening; another good reason to hide the truth from us.  This is the attempt to make us believe we are watching a Swedish movie in which no one does anything that a living human being would actually do in real life, but which works in surreal masterpieces and only uses up film time here.Here we are, sinking en masse into a morass (excuse me) of who are these people and why am I still part of their lives?  Is there an exit?  There is indeed.Clara (Sean's lover, remember?  Oh, that's right, you didn't know) grabs young Sean, asks him if he recognizes her, and when he doesn't, tells him who she is, i.e. his erstwhile lover -- which he would know if he were really the original Sean, which clearly he isn't.  She has figured out how he got the letters, etc, and reveals all both to him and us.Well, it is time for her to tell Anna the truth, but nope, that would be inconsistent with her character -- the smidgen of character we have been allowed to see.No, it is up to Sean to have his (second) identity crisis, return to Anna's apartment and take another bath (don't ask), this time without Anna in the tub with him, and now he tells her that he is not Sean after all; but he doesn't tell how he knows this (in addition to showing symptoms of multiple personality disease, young Sean also seems to have a great, though misguided, maturity).And this leads to the end.  Anna is first distraught, then angry, then remorseful.  This remorse is shown in the next scene in which she is on her knees in front of Joe, begging him to understand that she is not at fault for believing the ten year old kid was actually Sean and spurning Joe for this prepubescent dour child (I mean, after all, even if he were Sean, come on now, he's a child and in a new body and bad things happen even to good people, although a chance to get rich telling your story on Oprah doesn't seem that much of a bad thing, but giving up this man with whom she has supposedly fallen in love?!).  But wait a minute, this man she is pleading to, to forgive her and marry her, this is the same man that lifted this child off the ground, tossed him around a room, started to spank him, and heaven knows what else.  This is the man she wants?Well, remember the character of Anna.  She's nuts.  She never knew her first husband.  And she never let go of him either.  She never had any interest in the character of this young Sean.  She is probably the world's loneliest woman, certainly one of the world's most narcissistically obsessive.Oh, yes, Joe forgives her and says he will marry her.  And we see the wedding while removed from it.  And we see an ambiguous scene on a beach in which she may or may not be having a breakdown (or perhaps revealing one that occurred ages ago -- who knows?) and may or may not be receiving support from Joe.End of movie.Was it worth it?  More than not.  If you are going to get anything out of this movie, you need to see it from the second perspective, the perspective of the outsider who knows who the characters really are.  Four characters in this movie are true or interesting enough that one can learn from and appreciate them:  Anna, Joe, the child Sean, and the dead husband Sean, whom we can only infer from the story.  None of them are particularly likeable, though, especially in retrospect; but they can produce one hell of a conversation.See what you think.
summary: A Movie That Only Appears To Be About Reincarnation -- Warning: contains potential spoilers

reviewText: During a matinée on opening week, I was one of only four others who showed up to watch it. The movie addresses the complex topic of reincarnation and does not give any resolute, pat answers - which is simply too overwhelming for most audiences (and many critics). The acting is first class, the drama tight and effective; most of all the story is told with patience and emphasis on the minutia of the human perspective in the face of mortality and the elusive nature of human existence. Reincarnation is explored but is not necessarily the reason d'etre of the story - the concept of eternal love is the pulse of much of the narrative here.The director is not afraid to allow the emotions of a character to build and develop... often the camera stays close on the face of the principals for extended periods...which is nice and reassuring; it allows us the comfort of knowing that we are on a journey with a guide who is not going to blow his load at the first opportunity.A watershed for Kidman's character is the Wagner scene (which seems to be getting some unwarranted derision from one prominent 'thumbs down' critic). It forms a striking contrast to the manic technique now commonplace; I must say it is nice to have the camera on one face instead of jumping, cutting, zooming, etc. all over the place. It allows the viewer time to think, reflect and absorb the deeper intentions of the narrative.I just want to say that the film opens with on a good note and closes with one of the most haunting visuals ever portrayed in cinema. For those of you who have seen this movie you know what I am talking about, right? It is only a shame that the general population would rather see convoluted plots involving 'Saw'ed-off limbs rather than genuinely creative, worthwhile cinema

reviewText: I anxiously looked forward to this film (as I do with any film about reincarnation) and saw it in theaters before it quickly disappeared. I was severely disappointed, as this film was very slow moving, darkly lit, and purposefully vague. All that adds up to one somber and moody film. I left the theater feeling very "blah!" and that's not how I like feeling when I walk out of a movie theater.Nicole Kidman's performance was outstanding in this film (despite her severe hair cut) and I thought she should have been nominated for the Best Actress Oscar (it is among her best performances I've ever seen). Her performance is the biggest reason why I may end up buying this film (I liked it that much). She plays Anna, a woman who is about to be married after finally getting over her husband's death over a decade ago. But when a 10 year old boy comes into her life claiming to be Sean, her dead husband, with convincing sincerity, her doubts melt away despite her friends and family's skepticism.The best scene in this film was the one where everyone is gathered to hear a musician rehearse the wedding march (which is the best version I ever heard of that overfamiliar piece of music). Its disturbing to see a fully grown man get into a fight with a 10 year old boy over a woman. Apparently, that boy was able to get under a few people's skin with his insistence of being the reincarnation of Sean.The bathtub scene between Nicole Kidman and the boy bordered on bad taste (I couldn't help but think of Mary Kay Latourneau--the teacher who fell in love and went to prison for her inappropriate relationship with one of her students). I did like Anna's proding of the boy as they ate ice cream. She asked him how he planned to take care of her. It was mildly funny, but because this movie is so slow moving and dark...it really does try your patience. By the end, we have reason to doubt the boy's claim due to Anne Heche's insistence that Sean had really loved her, not Anna. The ending leaves Anna completely heartbroken as she realizes that she made a serious mistake in the decision she chose.Since I've read over 20 books on reincarnation, I have seen a remarkable consistency about how reincarnation is supposed to work and how all of us can find out about our former existences and what we are here to do in our current lifetimes...but this film touches on none of those ideas. Its merely about a love that doesn't die after the death of a spouse...and asks if its possible for the love to continue through the rebirth of one person, despite the age gap. The film certainly could have been much better...the topic of reincarnation demands a serious undertaking.  Unfortunately, this film is not it. They left it purposefully vague, perhaps to initiate viewers to discuss it in film circles...but they forgot to make the kind of film that a broader audience would be interested in seeing. I saw it in an empty theater with only one other person, and this film didn't last a month in theaters. Anyone who decides to watch it on dvd will understand why it didn't do well in theaters. Its a shame, because the topic is worth a serious film and the performances of Nicole Kidman and the boy are worth watching.

reviewText: "Birth"  is fascinating, but in a sick, sick kind of way. It never loses the audience's attention.To start with, the plot is extremely innovative. Main character Anna is set to marry a man named Joseph - 10 years after the death of her first husband, Sean. But a 10-year-old boy arrives on the scene, claiming to be a reincarnation of the dead husband. His name, indeed, is Sean.Sean seems to know intimate details about Anna that only the "real" Sean would know - where "they" met, the fact that they "did it" on Anna's brother's couch. He warns Anna not to marry Joseph. Slowly, Anna starts to believe, and fall in love with, him.Cameron Bright does an excellent job of playing the child, coming off as creepy beyond his years and yet innocent at times. He's clearly in the top tier of modern child actors.The movie's most controversial scene, of course, occurs when the young Sean gets in a bathtub with Anna. Yes, naked, though there is no nudity in the shots. Critics including Robert Ebert have called it "care[ful] and tact[ful]," but it is indeed rather gag-inducing. Such an act, regardless of the circumstances and the manner in which it's filmed, is hard to excuse unless followed by a prison sentence. The movie would be much better off without it.The other scenes are excellent, however. Anna and her rich family (they all seem to live under one roof, oddly) react realistically and with skepticism. As the plot develops and Anna contemplates a relationship with Sean, her relatives and fiancee react more seriously, and even with violence.These elements make the movie easily worth seeing, as it is thought-provoking and very disturbing. The script is fiction at its best.To the film's detriment, though, is the cinematography. Striving too hard for an "artsy" vibe, the movie's flow is interrupted by awkward pauses, soap opera-esque zooming on characters' staring expressions and a very odd final sequence.In the end, the characters come through realistically, and the plot winds down to a totally unexpected conclusion. But in the process of making the ending come out of nowhere, the producers didn't bother to check their facts from earlier in the flick. Any analysis would spoil the ending, but it leaves the audience confused.All in all, despite its flaws and the facts that don't line up, "Birth" is one of the better movies to come out this year.

reviewText: Considering it is the story of a budding love affair between a fashionable New York woman and a 10-year-old boy who claims to be her dead husband, "Birth" could not afford to make one small misstep toward being cheap or tawdry. And, remarkably, it does not. In fact, it's quiet, creepy and brilliant, bursting with a strange kind of confidence that director co-writer/director Jonathan Glazer knows just what to do with this story, and does it.The opening scene immediately sets that tone - a beautiful shot of a man running through Central Park, in high winter, passing under one tunnel, then halfway through another before he collapses. We are then shown the birth of a boy, the title card of ten years later, and a shot of the woman, Anna (Nicole Kidman), touching a gravestone. She returns to the car and says to a man, "okay." She's just accepted his proposal for marriage.Not long after, the boy, Sean (Cameron Bright), appears at a birthday party in Anna's expensive apartment. It's a shot of giant birthday cake illuminating Anna's whole family as they see the boy for the first time. Sean pulls Anna aside. "It's me, Sean," he says. "Your husband."The movie presents this material like a short story would, with tact, detail and suspense. Anna is at first amused. Then curious. Then bothered. Then, in an extrodinary sequence that focuses on Kidman's face for a full two minutes at the symphony, deeply shaken. Bright plays the boy with a quiet certitude beyond his years, and besides, this Sean *knows* things. How? Is it Sean reincarnated? The movie provides one direct answer, but, piecing the details together, there are moments that answer doesn't address, least of all the opening sequence. "Birth" is comfortable enough to be unsettling and sad: There a lot of people aside from Anna who never got over the first Sean.Kidman, in the Mia Farrow haircut, is excellent as the dignified, intelligent but lonely Anna, who parades a polished facade until she encounters the boy. Glazer likes Kidman's face a lot, especially when her mouth isn't moving, and he frames it with spring colors and wood surfaces. Bright is convincing as Sean. Danny Huston plays Anna's fiancee, one of those burnished, proper, comfy men who aren't exactly rude so much as accustomed to things going according to plan. When they don't, his reaction is childish, but anguished in its own way. Lauren Bacall, Allison Elliot and Arliss Howard are members of Anna's disbelieving family, while Anne Heche, in a small but commanding performance, is the wild card, Anna's friend.The movie's real star is Glazer. His Euro treatment of this story - so different from his debut, "Sexy Beast" - is cool and professional, a throwback to Cassevetes, Kubrick, Polanski, Bogdanovich. The shots have been chosen with care, less for the plot than for the mood, which is more important with this subject matter. Glazer favors the long shot here, many of them, yet gets up close with Anna and Sean. The controverisal scene, where the two share a bathtub, is a little shocking but not tasteless. It wasn't entirely necessary, but it achieves its aim of taking this mystery - of Sean, of Anna's own feelings - seriously. Viewers owe "Birth" the same respect.

reviewText: This film is a psychological mystery that calls to mind the works of Stanley Kubrick and Steven Speilberg. Much controversy was made over this film when it was released - and understandably so - but it is so well acted, and handled with such subtlety that you become completely engrossed with the story. Nicole Kidman was nominated for a Golden Globe for her performance, and I believe that she should have been nominated for an Oscar.The story is about a woman named Anna, who is preparing to marry her second husband, Joseph. Her first husband, Sean, passed away a few years ago, and she is still greiving his death. One day, a ten year old boy shows up at her mother's birthday party unannounced, and tells her that he is her late husband. At first, she forcefully asks him to leave, but he refuses to leave her alone. He knows things about Sean that no one else would have known. He knows intimate details about her friends and family, and soon it becomes overwhelming, and she starts to believe that it is a possibility that this young man could be the reincarnation of her husband. Most of the film is about her inner struggle with this complicated situation, but the best thing about the film is that it handles it with common sense. The characters act realistically, and that makes all the difference. This film avoids sappiness at all costs, and that makes it all the more powerful and unsettling.Young co-star Cameron Bright is quite good in his complicated role. People may say that he is simply imitating Haley Joel Osment, but they would be wrong. This is not your typical "creepy kid" role. He brings real depth to the material, and is totally convincing. Screen veteran Lauren Bacall is always a joy to watch, and she plays Kidman's mother.This is probably one of the most misunderstood films of 2004. Yes, the ending does seem like a cop-out, but I believe it is open to multiple interpretations. BIRTH also boasts some excellent cinematography from Harris Savides, and a haunting score by Alexandre Desplat.

reviewText: This is not a movie for those who require nice, tidy, scientific conclusions. This is an odd and eerie tale of...pyschological disturbances? emotional manipulation coupled with uncanny existential coincidence? reincarnation? are there really ANY coincidences?Although a 'reasonably conclusive' explanation is alluded to, the film wisely strays from allowing it to take hold in any convincing, satisfying way.Which is to say, the pragmatic explanation *could* be a red herring; the subtle revelations are easily buried, and the effectivness of the misdirection(possibly)lies in the viewers inherent tendency to seek solid, familiar footing in what and how they're attuned with in the daily round of life which largely disavows lending credence to the paranormal. Yet, as many people know, strange, unexplainable things DO occur all the time, and perhaps we aren't as wise and self assured as we'd like to believe.Don't expect any hard evidence in "Birth" to convince you of this; the telling rests within the atmosphere and underlying vibes of the characters. It is one thing to claim understanding of something which is widely accepted, and quite another to instinctively 'know' something that may defy common perception.Sean's mistress claims, "You would've come to me first, but you didn't".Yet, Sean *did* trail her at the onset, didn't he?Sean's mistress claims that Sean gave her the unopened love letters from his wife in order to prove that "he loved me more".Perhaps.However, maybe he gave them to her unopened because he honestly loved wis wife and couldn't read them, nor wanted to keep them, out of dire guilt. And when he "returned", he instinctively honed directly in on that love in his life which he deeply regretted jeopardizing? Maybe the soul of Sean's mistress held sway over him in a way he wasn't able to resist in that particular existence, and once freed, returned and sought out what mattered most? Or maybe Sean is an emotionally unbalanced ten year old boy who, although not done out of malice, effectively manipulates several lives?To be honest, this is a difficult movie. There's no other way of stating it. It casts light on aspects of our spirituality, on Love - on what that can possibly entail in the grander scheme of human existence - that, given the substance of this story, can seem cruel and unbearable.However, this is ultimately the stuff of worthy, challanging art which requires and demands the humanity of the viwer. It calls accepted pieties and doctrines into question, and unlike so many common movies which merely serve to opiate the masses, does not make light of the mysterious complexities of the heart and soul.

reviewText: Oh man...This film came so close to blowing me away.So close...Birth could have been a masterpiece...if only it could have found a way out of its own dilemma.The Amazon review states: Birth is a melancholy chamber piece, its pensive mood sustained by nearly sub-sonic nuances in a fine, thematically developed score by Alexandre Desplat.All so true.  The cinematography, music, lighting, set design, costuming, casting, performances--but oh, especially the music--all add up to one of the freshest, most original movie-going experiences in a long time.  The premise is highly original.  The set-up is bold.  There are some brave scenes in this movie.  I know some people found them "distasteful."  I didn't.  A little audacious, maybe even hard to watch at times, but necessary for the story.The problem with films where you weave a very unusual tale, where there's an idea that knocks you off-kilter, is the solution, the ending, has to be equally stunning. Anything less is a cop-out, and the audience walks away feeling cheated.Well, hope this doesn't spoil it for you, but you're gonna feel cheated.  Big time.  The last ten or fifteen minutes are some of the lamest material attached to some of the greatest material that I have ever seen.  All through this film I kept thinking "How on *earth* are they going to pull this off?"  Well, they didn't.The performances are spot on, although I think these wealthy penthouse folks are a bit more indulgent to Sean than such people would be in real life--I think real rich folks would be more afraid this is a set up to get at their money.  But there's something about this film that just feels and looks so right.  Director Jonathan Glazer has a stylish eye and a great feel for rhythm (don't believe the reviews that say this film will put you to sleep; only if you're already dead will that happen).  And he manages to convey "interior" moments brilliantly, which is one of the hardest things to do in cinema.  There's an incredible scene where Kidman's character goes to the opera.  We crane in on her face as she and her fiancé sit down: the camera holds on her face for something like two minutes while she comes to a conclusion.  The music and the photography and Kidman's perfect portrayal as a wealthy and polished woman who is nonetheless very soft at the center and somewhat off-center since the death of her husband combine to create a completely satisfying moment, one that changes the direction of the film at that point and propels it into the second act flawlessly--and it's all done without a single word of dialogue being spoken by anyone.  That's cinema.  One of the writers is none other than Jean-Claude Carrière, who also wrote the screenplay for The Unbearable Lightness of Being, another "interior" movie, this one with a perfectly-realized ending.The other performances are also very fine--measured, elegant, low-key, and focused, except for Anne Heche, who is more neurotic than the others, and perfectly so.  It's almost as though we're watching a well-written and directed stage play--that even though I just got done lauding how cinematic the film otherwise is.  Well, it's that good, combining the best of many artforms--until that grossly misconceived ending.  Yes, there is some derivation from The Sixth Sense, more in terms of its oddball conception than in execution.  But I think this film is more stylish, more confident, even if Sixth Sense managed an ending that surprised us and yet was perfectly logical within the world it created, and this film did not.  There are also echoes of Rosemary's Baby,  especially with Nicole's hair and slightly Mia Farrowish voice, although that film, by a director I greatly admire, Roman Polansky, never quite worked for me.  David Thomson, in his creepy book on Nicole Kidman, describes the film as "Henry james on the edge of the supernatural," which is just about right.Despite my disappointment in Birth, I'm going to recommend it, especially if you like "out of the box" films as I do.  Just, when you plunk down your four dollars or whatever it costs to rent it, be prepared for a disappointment at the end.  --Maybe video stores should discount the rental a buck for the lame finish.The DVD picture is crisp and appropriately subdued.  No extras except a trailer--some commentaries would have been nice.  There are also a few featurettes you can access from your computer if you have a DVD-ROM drive and you're willing to let the disc install some extra software.  I'm not.Sigh...it *could* have been a great film, it really could have.

reviewText: A 10 year-old boy approaches to a middle-age lady who lost her husband ten years ago, and the boy says to her with a very serious face that HE is the reincarnation of her dead husband. Is he really saying the truth? Or is this just a prank (which must be a very cruel one). Or, is it the boy's delusion? The plot of `Birth' is intriguing, with several questions about the way we perceive hard reality, but the film fails to develop it beyond its initial premise, which needs more careful treatment.I know Nicole Kidman is a gifted actress, and she does not disappoint us as Anna who is going to marry Joseph (Danny Huston). She lost her husband Sean ten years ago, and it is suggested that she has just recovered from the shock of his death.When Anna is about to embark on her new life, another `Sean' enters her life, as a ten-year-old boy (Cameron Bright) who lives downstairs in the same building where Joseph lives. This new Sean not only claims that he is the reincarnation of her lost husband, but sends her a message telling not to marry Joseph. Anna at first does not take him seriously, but as the resolute boy comes back again, she starts to look at him differently, or in short, falls in love with this `Sean.'I admit the film's merit as study of our belief, heart, love, or whatever worth mentioning in film, but `Birth' just fails to convince. I'm not talking about the `bathtub' scene some may find embarrassing. I am talking about the character of Anna, which needs more finesse, or subtlety. If you have to convince us that a level-headed lady can really fall in love with a ten-year-old boy who says he is her dead husband, you need more than frequent close-ups of Nicole Kidman (with her good acting though), the film's beautiful images and evocative music score. I know what the director Jonathan Glazer is trying to do. Among the many mysteries in this world, our heart is the most incomprehensive one. Still our heart does not respond to the little boy simply because the script tells it to do so.For all its intention, I could not help feeling that what Anna is doing is just unbelievable. `Birth' is full of visual mystification, but its content is not as substantial as other better films like `Under the Sand.'
summary: Visually Evocative, But Its Content Fails to Convince

reviewText: Nicole Kidman is an absolute wonder.  There is no limit to how she astounds me with the nuance she brings to the roles she takes on.  As one of the most acclaimed actresses of her day, all I can say is that she deserves it.  It is also adimirable of Kidman that she chooses such challenging roles.  Just take a minute to consider the people she has played: an arguably insane woman suffering from intense paranoia in 'The Others'; a prostitute who breaks free from her belief that love doesn't pay in 'Moulin Rouge!'; Virginia Woolf on the verge of suicide in 'The Hours'; a Scarlett O'Hara-esque woman longing for a love lost in war in 'Cold Mountain'; the suffering Grace who is subjected to slavery in 'Dogville;' and now, in 'Birth,' Anna, a woman who, after finally getting over the loss of her husband ten years after his death, is approached by a ten-year-old boy claiming to be him reincarnated.  Quite the impressive list, no?  It is growing and will probably rival that of Meryl Streep or Cate Blanchett.  As mentioned, 'Birth' provides Kidman with yet another complex role, and again, she is perfect (in fact, more than perfect) and this is starting to become an inevitability.In 'Birth,' after a little boy named Sean approaches Kidman claiming to be her dead husband Sean, Kidman's Anna begins to suffer immensely; you are able to see it in the way she moves, the way she speaks and carries herself.  In a cramped hallway, Sean's father tells him to apologize for his nagging, and as Sean insists that he will not stop, Anna bends over, looks him in the eye, and says, "You're hurting me.  You know that?  You're hurting me."  Kidman brings so much power to those words, to every word spoken.  When she slowly begins to accept that this boy may after all be her dead husband, the character Anna's hopefulness and possible delusion are appropriately convincing.  It takes an Oscar-worthy performance to cause a situation as far fetched as the one in 'Birth' to seem real in the most painfully visceral sense, and Kidman never loses her balance.  However, it is not just Kidman's performance that makes the film so effectively suspenseful.The perspective with which director Jonathan Glazer and his fellow screenwriters approach 'Birth' is that of an elite cynic, like many of the central characters in the film (in fact, during 'Birth's opening, you hear the real Sean reassuring the audience at some sort of conference that he is a man of science, that he does not allow himself to buy into such "nonsense").  The approach is successful in making the film unsettling because it is the approach most in a world that needs solid proof would take if such a claim were made, especially considering the fact that the concept of reincarnation is of religious origin.  One can relate to Anna's mindset of uncertainty mixed with nostalgia.  When Anna's sense of longing is matched by strong possibility, the screenplay and direction make us feel involved in the situation rather than pushed away by its absurdity.  The controversial bath tub scene, though modestly handled, is the single large flaw in Glazer's attempts to universalize the film, because it alienates rather than invites.Throughout 'Birth,' there is a lack of build to its shattering climactic scene between a bitingly precise Anne Heche and Cameron Bright, the young actor who plays ten-year-old Sean.  However, there are many masterful moments conjured by the film making team that are immensely memorable, which is much more than most films can offer.  Consider when Anna's husband, Joseph (Danny Huston), unleashes his anger toward young Sean in the midst of a wedding announcement, or when Anna and Joseph attend an opera following young Sean's collapse after being refused by her; Kidman's face contorts in sadness, in happiness, longing, a moment so magical and appropriately elongated that one feels nearly overwhelmed with power.  While viewing the film you are able to tell its director is a strong one that knows what he's doing and how to elicit concrete reaction from his audience.  These many moments of greatness are alone worth the price of admission.One of those many glorious scenes is the opening sequence: it is simply Sean, a figure wrapped in warm, black clothing, jogging through Central Park through the cool curtain of snow.  It manages to encapsulate the tone of 'Birth.'  First of all, it best exemplifies Harris Savides' mesmerizing camera work, slow and elongated to allow the power of each moment to sink in (this is reflective of a Stanley Kubrick film).  Alexandre Desplat's best-of-the-year dramatic score dots the sequence with both delicate and grandiose undertones, growing most quiet when the word 'Birth' spirals out over a snowy pathway while Sean runs in the background, a lone triangle tapping its way through a wintry solace.  Never before has an opening sequence alone been enough to fully absorb me into a film.At 'Birth's end, two answers to the film's question are presented: both are equally plausible, which in turn futhers the film's ability to intrigue and to convince.  Also, the ending continues to provoke thoughts back to earlier parts of the film; a case of fine construction on Jonathan Glazer's part (apparently, he spent months editing and re-editing in order to create the pitch-perfect effect, and I believe his work paid off).  As the credits roll following perhaps the most devastatingly ambiguous image in a film I've seen within the last three or four years, we are left with the memory of great acting, great editing, great camera work, great writing, great direction, and great scoring.  Honestly, what more does one ask for from a film?  'Birth' is impeccably skilled to every last detail, and it is a shame that it has been so wrongfully underrated by the critics and by the public.  However, I am not surprised since the disregarding of great work has become as common as expecting something profound from Nicole Kidman every time she goes to work.
summary: Great sophomore effort from Jonathan Glazer

reviewText: Nicole Kidman stars as Anna, a woman who is remarrying 10 years after the death of her first husband.  Enter a 10-year-old boy named Sean (Cameron Bright), who claims to be the reincarnation of her dead husband, also named Sean.  Everyone is skeptical until the boy begins to reveal information that only the older Sean could have known.  Is he truly the re-birth of Kidman's husband?The plot outline sounded intriguing to me, with a multitude of possible directions to explore.  For example, I would be interested in what Anna thinks about someone claiming to be her husband.  What feelings did it bring forth for her?  Unfortunately, all parties involved in this film botched it massively.  The script never examines HOW these people feel about the events.  Scene after scene is filled with people doubting that the child is Sean, but no one discusses what the older Sean meant to them or what these boy's claims elicit in them.  The script is also devoid of any humor, taking instead a dreadfully serious tone.In addition, the plot takes several salacious turns, most notably during several scenes in which young Sean makes intimate overtures to Kidman (sharing a bathtub, kissing her).  These scenes are not graphic but quite disturbing nevertheless.  In another scene, Kidman begins exploring with young Sean what would happen if they did become a couple again, asking him if he's ever made love to a girl.  Not many 10-year-old boys are sexually active, Nicole!  The movie ends up coming off creepy, and one is left wondering how in the world the savvy Kidman became involved in this mess.Directed by Jonathan Glazer who did the far superior "Sexy Beast," the movie has a terrific look -- icy and gorgeous.  However, the cinematography is the only redeeming quality.  Kidman is good in a few scenes, but her character is so under-developed that it's difficult to call her overall performance good.  She did, however, somewhat inexplicably receive a Golden Globe nomination.Ultimately, "Birth" is a movie with an interesting idea, but it resoundingly fails to explore the scenario with any nuance.  The ending is a particularly cryptic and unsatisfying disaster.  The DVD also has very few extras and no director's commentary, disallowing further understanding of the film.  Not recommended.

reviewText: Nicole Kidman plays a woman who is about to remarry after the death of her husband some time ago.  One particular night a boy approaches her claiming to be her husband re-incarnated. reviewText: Ever since The Hours, Nicole Kidman has not made good choices when it comes to picking movies or maybe she's not trying hard enough anymore like her early work(To Die For). She's pretty convincing in this movie, but let's face it, it's a weak film, and doing a 3-minute close-up shot in a scene and making the audience like myself wonder if she was going to break down into tears or something did not work. There was some good moments in this film, but it suffered from a lack of thrill and a poor plotline.Anna(Kidman) was about to get married again after her ex-husband(Sean) died 10 years ago, and a 10 year-old boy named Sean (Cameron Bright)appeared at her mother's(Lauren Bacall) apartment to tell her he's "Sean". She freaked out when he told her not to married his fiance. At first, she thought the kid was some psycho playing a head game, but eventually the kid told him many things that only her dead husband knew about. So she started to take him seriously.The fiance, family members, and the kid's parents were all puzzled by the situation. Anna was on the verge of breaking the engagement off and run away with the kid, so that in 11 years he will be 21, and they can get married. That's when the dead Sean's lover(Anne Heche) came in and solved the mystery....Cameron Bright did a very good job in this film, because he had to be realistic and mature. He's as good as other kid actors like Rory Culkin. Anne Heche stole a few scenes with very little screen time. Lauren Bacall's role was underwritten and ornamental, and she was mostly in "group scenes". The unexpected ending didn't connect well to everything in the movie. I am not going to spoil it for you, but I didn't like it. Considered it's reincarnation theme is very similar to P.S., the latter is more enjoyable and ended better.
